variant.question: You are flying when you receive a broadcast from ATS, advising of the emergency descent of an aircraft in your area. What action should you take?

options.text: Continue on the present heading and maintain level.
Clear the area and stand by on the appropriate frequency.
Change to the previous frequency and request instructions.
Transmit on the frequency your call sign, position, track, and level.

variant.question: According to ICAO Doc. 4444, describe what actions a pilot shall make after receiving a broadcast about another aircraft's emergency descent.

options.text: Navigate as deemed appropriate by the pilot and acknowledge to the appropriate ATS unit that the notification about the emergency descent was received.
Immediately acknowledge the receipt of the broadcast and request further instructions
Navigate as deemed appropriate by the pilot and turn on all aircraft exterior lights (commensurate with appropriate operating limitations).

Continue according to current clearance and maintain a listening watch on the frequency in use for any further instructions from the ATS unit, and watch for conflicting traffic both visually and by reference to ACAS (if equipped).

variant.question: An aircraft on a controlled flight is in contact with Paris ATC when it encounters a rapid decompression. The flight crew is required to initiate an emergency descent immediately. Who should they contact to declare an emergency?

options.text: They should contact Paris ATC or switch to 121.5 MHz.
They should contact 121.5 MHz and request a clearance to declare an emergency.
They should contact Eurocontrol first and if Eurocontrol is unavailable, contact Paris ATC to declare an emergency.
They should contact Paris ATC and request for a frequency change to declare an emergency.

variant.question: Both an aeroplane (call sign AB139) and a helicopter (call sign AT139) are operating on the same approach frequency. Which of the following actions should the ATC controller take, in order to avoid the potential for call sign confusion?

options.text: Request a temporary change in one of the two call signs.
Instruct both the aeroplane and the helicopter to change their call signs permanently.
Continue using the existing call signs and exercise caution to avoid confusion.
Make use of the abbreviated call signs, for the helicopter and the aeroplane.

options.text: SIX ZERO ZERO
RVR constituent letters
RUNWAY VISUAL RANGE and SIX ZERO ZERO
RUNWAY VISUAL RANGE

variant.question: A strayed aircraft is an aircraft..

options.text: flying in a given area but whose identity has not been established.
which has lost radio contact.
which has penetrated controlled airspace without clearance.
which has deviated significantly from its intended track or which reports that it is lost.

variant.question: During cruise on route to your destination, you hear over the radio that another aircraft is performing an emergency descent in the area due to a depressurisation problem. What actions should you take?

options.text: Maintain heading and speed
Clear the area
Perform an emergency descent
Broadcast your call sign, location, altitude and heading
